context: Actually an orbital flight is scheduled for July 1st, though it might be a bit optimistic!

replies.context: Slight correction the aspirational goal is sometime in July.  But in any event very soon in rocket development times.  I do think it will happen before the end of the year.  And the initial orbital flights will not be manned nor the craft man rated yet.

Probably very optimistic, the Booster hasn't even flown yet.  STARSHIP is actually intended to be the 2nd stage - orbiter of the stack.  STARSHIP also hasn't flown with the necessary heatshield system that's to be mounted to its' belly.

Will it happen?  I believe it will ... the real question is when will it happen.

replies.context: Moving forward private industry should.

SpaceX and NASA aren't designing for the same missions.  SpaceX designed Dragon to get to the ISS.  NASA designed Orion to get to the ISS and the moon.  Starship is designed to go to Mars but it's unlikely with current engine technology it will ever get there.  NASA designed Artemis for the moon and beyond.  Artemis can lift more than anything SpaceX has designed and NASA is re-visiting nuclear propulsion work because it realizes chemical rockets are too slow.  I look at NASA and SpaceX as the tortoise and the hare.  You would be remiss to discount NASA.

context: Congrats to the Musk team! I do have to chuckle though. I remember a lot of the old sci-fi movies from the 50s and 60s showing space ships taking off from the Earth and landing back on Earth or on another planet this same way.  So there is some humor that we think we have advanced so incredibly far when we are over 50 years away from those early sci-dreams. I'm not sure we are as advanced as we think we are. Still congrats for making the concept actually work.
I had wondered what happened to all those old retired Ford Pinto engineers.

replies.context: I doubt it would have made a bit of difference.  Until the last 15 years there were no companies with the interest, or billions in surplus resources, to pursue private manned space flight.  And as soon as such companies appeared (e.g. Virgin, Blue Origin, SpaceX), government began relaxing the rules and encouraging them.

We didn't have the technology to make things like SpaceX's reusable rockets happen years ago. It only took a person like Elon Musk, who isn't even 50 yet, to develop that technology (and all of Tesla's groundbreaking technology as well) since nobody else bothered to do it. The guy is a living legend...

context: I am looking forward to the days when we begin construction of vessels in space for long distance traveling.  I hope it will be within my own lifetime.

replies.context: Why. At the rate of expansion of the universe we will never be able to travel anywhere except in our own solar system.  Even that will be challenging enough with our propulsion system. It's hard enough just getting off the planet.

Because exploration and invention is at the heart of our species.  We could not get around the earth in a day a century ago, now it occurs routinely.  Humans are exceptional at moving forward with tools and finding solutions... and those solutions often affect the rest of the world in unexpected ways, often good, sometimes bad (usually due to how they are used rather than the invention being inherently bad).

context: My cousin works at SpaceX's McGregor, TX facility and said that SpaceX plans on using Starship to travel from point-to-point locations anywhere on Earth in under 30 mins. This is the beginning of the end of the airline industry as we know it...

replies.context: Not really.  Starship/Superheavy will make a horrendous noise, orders of magnitude more than a jumbo jet, and there's no getting around that.  Cities already have trouble dealing with normal airport noise so will never allow something like that within 25 miles of an inhabited area (which is almost nowhere, except maybe the Southwest desert).  Maybe it could be launched from barges off coastal cities, but that introduces a new set of challenges.   Airlines aren't worried.
Yep, that's already in the works. SpaceX already has 2 former oil rigs that they're converting to launch pads as we speak, with many many more on the way
That's for launching to space, not intra-city.
They'll be used for both space and Earth-to-Earth travel. Musk has even said so himself on multiple occasions...
It will happen.

I guarantee you, it will not, not in this century at least.

I worked in the aviation industry and the economic margins are thin at best.  Concord was never economically viable, and the Boeing SST was cancelled because they knew it never would be.  And they were orders of magnitude cheaper to operate than SS/SH will ever be.  Only a handful of people could justify $50,000 tickets to save a few hours flying time, and they have their own jets with sleeping accommodations.  And not every city is near the ocean, and most aren't prepared to spend billions on infrastructure on a new transportation system.

It's Elon Musk we're talking about here. There's never been anyone like him before. He always puts his money where his mouth is. It will happen and it'll happen faster than most people realize. They've built and landed an entirely new type of rocket, which has never been done before, in less than 2 years time.  SpaceX plans on building a new Starship every 3-5 days and literally sending hundreds of them at a time to the moon and Mars. Plus, for Earth-to-Earth travel, you won't need the massive Super Heavy booster to get to orbit. That's the beauty of reusable rockets
you will be sitting on the launchpad longer than 30 minutes..

context: Starship landing nominal (SLN) much better than rapid unplanned disassembly (RUD).  I hope his humor is this dry on SNL.

This endeavor to put man on Mars is a boondoggle and a waste of time and money. We have much too much medical and infrastructure issues here on earth to be thrown it at a rock 33.9 million miles away. Nothing of real value is going to come of this because all it is, is a pat on the back to get there. So what, it's there and worthless to us at this stage of human evolution. It is a cold inhospitable rock that humans cannot comfortably or economically reside on. We should be putting more emphasis to  cure cancer or put an end to world hunger, fix our infrastructures and global water needs.
